learning_outcomes.description: Recognise fundamental building structural principles, construction techniques, and materials, including concrete, timber, brick and steel.
Investigate and identify building materials with suitable properties for given design applications.
Use structural system and material solutions for simple, small scale structure and construction.
Identify and interpret relevant building standards and codes.
Recognise and use the basics of 2D architectural drawing and documentation conventions.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

Students develop a visual and analytical notebook that documents selected structural typologies (corresponding to the weekly topics and site visits). The notebook will include annotated drawings, sketches, diagrams, and written explanations describing material properties, structural behaviour, assembly methods, and real‑world examples. Where possible, dimensions should be added. This assessment strengthens observational skills and reinforces students’ ability to communicate constructional understanding using architectural drawing conventions.

All drawings, sketches and diagrams must be completed by hand using analogue tools and submitted as a single bound document of A3 format (landscape). The digital copy must to be submitted in .PDF format (with sufficient resolution of carefully scanned drawings) as a single document. Annotations, notes observations, and photographs can be added digitally. Handwritten notes must be legible.

Complex / authentic assessment using AI and/or MT to support learning:

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The School of Architecture, Design and Planning uses Blackboard and Turnitin for assessment submission. Turnitin is accessed through the course Blackboard site. Turnitin also checks for plagiarism or instances where the original work of others is not appropriately acknowledged. Uploaded files must contain readable text and not be rasterised. Uploaded files must contain readable text and not be rasterised. Students are advised to commence assignment uploads with sufficient amount of time (consider possible technical problems with computers, internet speed, etc). After successfully submitting an assignment through Turnitin, a ‘Submission Complete!’ screen will be displayed. It is the student’s responsibility to check assignment preview and confirm successful submission. If the ‘Submission Complete!’ screen isn’t displayed, the student should regard the submission as unsuccessful. Students should download a copy of the digital receipt as proof they have submitted the assignment. Students who are experiencing upload issues must advise the Course Coordinator immediately by email and should include screenshots and a copy of the assessment for submission. To meet professional accreditation, public engagement and quality assurance obligations, digital copies of all course assessment items must be submitted in addition to any hard copy submission requirements specified in individual Course / Studio Outlines. Any physical models should be photographed and a minimum of two photographs describing the complete and full model must be included in the digital submission.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 2 - Structural Challenge and Glossary Quiz
assessments.due_date:
20/04/2026 2:00 pm

The quiz is taken in-person, the time is limited to 1 hour from 2pm till 3pm.

The quiz will take place in the studio 51-223 (unless specified otherwise through the Blackboard)
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

A timed 1-hour quiz tests students' understanding of the basic structural definitions and terminology and evaluates their comprehension of key structural principles.

By learning and correctly applying foundational vocabulary, students build the technical literacy required for interpreting construction drawings, engaging with weekly tutorials, and progressing to more complex structural principles including load paths, bracing, frame behaviour, and common techniques used in construction. The quiz prepares students for professional expectations of technical competency by assessing both conceptual understanding and applied reasoning.

In-person assessment prohibits use of AI or MT: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.due_date:
8/06/2026 4:00 pm

Digital Submission: Via Blackboard by 4pm

Hardcopy Submission: in the studio (51-223) from 2pm till 4pm
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:

For this assessment, students will develop a set of detailed architectural drawings (plans, sections, elevations, details and schedules) and a structural model describing a small one-story framed structure of their own design with the joints, the system, materials, structural performance, dimensions, etc.

Each drawing must use correct architectural conventions, appropriate scales (1:50 or 1:20 for plans, sections and elevations and 1:20, 1:10 or 1:5 for details/joints) , and clear annotation practices. The submission must also articulate the structure’s system, joints, material behaviour, and overall structural performance. This capstone assessment synthesises all skills learned throughout the semester — observation, measurement, documentation, material knowledge, and structural understanding.

The structural model is to be completed to appropriate scale (1:50 or 1:20), and effectively express structural performance and materiality of the designed structure.

The drawings must be completed by hand using analogue tools and submitted as a single bound document of A3 format (landscape). The digital copy must be submitted in .PDF format (with sufficient resolution of carefully scanned drawings) as a single document. Annotations, notes observations, and photographs of the model can be added digitally. Handwritten notes must be legible.

Complex / authentic assessment using AI and/or MT to support learning:

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

Students are advised to commence assignment uploads with sufficient amount of time (consider possible technical problems with computers, internet speed, etc). If the ‘Submission Complete!’ screen isn’t displayed, the student should regard the submission as unsuccessful. Students who are experiencing upload issues must advise the Course Coordinator immediately by email and should include screenshots and a copy of the assessment for submission. To meet professional accreditation, public engagement and quality assurance obligations, digital copies of all course assessment items must be submitted in addition to any hard copy submission requirements specified in individual Course / Studio Outlines. Any physical models should be photographed and a minimum of two photographs describing the complete and full model must be included in the digital submission.
